sn48.41:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
sn48.41:4.3: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and sat warming his back in the last rays of the sun.
sn48.41:5.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
sn48.41:5.2: bowed, and while massaging the Buddha’s limbs he said:
sn48.41:5.4: how the complexion of your skin is no longer pure and bright. Your limbs are flaccid and wrinkled, and your body is stooped. And it’s apparent that there’s been a deterioration in your faculties
sn48.41:5.5: of eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.”
sn48.41:6.2: When young you’re liable to grow old; when healthy you’re liable to get sick; and when alive you’re liable to die.
sn48.41:6.3: The complexion of the skin is no longer pure and bright. The limbs are flaccid and wrinkled, and the body is stooped. And it’s apparent that there’s been a deterioration in the faculties
sn48.41:6.4: of eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.”
sn48.41:7.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn48.41:7.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn48.41:8.3: That’s how much this delightful puppet
sn48.41:8.4: is ground down by old age.
sn48.41:9.1: Even if you live for a hundred years,
